thread.title: Britons could lose £1.1 billion in forgotten spare change when new pound coin enters circulation
thread.title_full: Britons could lose £1.1 billion in forgotten spare change when new pound coin enters circulation

author: Lauren Davidson
title: Britons could lose £1.1 billion in forgotten spare change when new pound coin enters circulation
text:
“Look after the pennies and the pounds will look after themselves” could prove to be untrue if Britons do not cash in their spare change , Mastercard has warned.
P iggy bank savers stand to lose £1.1 billion worth of loose change stashed in jars and drawers when the current £1 coin goes out of circulation later this year, the credit card company said.
The coin, which was first introduced in 1983, is being replaced for the first time in more than 30 years in a bid to tackle counterfeit fraud. Around one in 30 £1 coins currently in the system are believed to be fake.
However, 87 per cent of Britons are unaware of the October 15 deadline to spend their current £1 coins , according to Mastercard’s survey of 2,000 people.
The study found that people tend to have £15 in £1 coins lying around in their home, rising to £25 among young adults aged 18 to 24.
Just 17 per cent of respondents said they knew about the introduction of the new coin on March 28.
The new 12-sided coin comes into circulation on March 28 Credit: David Rose “We were shocked to discover just how few people are aware of when the current £1 coin goes out of circulation,” said Mark Barnett, president of Mastercard UK and Ireland.
L ast month, the Treasury urged savers to check in coat pockets and sofa cushions for forgotten £1 coins. 
“We are calling on everybody – from conscientious children saving pocket money in piggy banks to families who like to hold on to their coins for a rainy day – to be ready for this change," chief secretary to the Treasury David Gauke said at the time. 
We were shocked to discover just how few people are aware of when the current £1 coin goes out of circulation “You have until autumn to spend your round pounds or exchange them for the edgy new version at your bank.”
T he new 12-sided coin, featuring a gold-coloured band around a silver plate similar to the £2 coin, will be “the most secure coin in the world” when it is introduced on 28 March, according to the Royal Mint. Thinner, lighter and larger than the current £1 coin, with a diameter around 1mm bigger than the current coin, the replacement also has milled edges, a hologram-like image and a “hidden high security feature” to thwart future counterfeiting.
As of March 2014, there were 1.55bn £1 coins in circulation. The Royal Mint is introducing 1.5bn of the new coin, and the current ones will cease to become legal tender in mid-October.
